12.72.text: I'm 150 feet down an illegal mine shaft in Ghana.

19.12.text: The air is thick with heat and dust,

26.65.text: I can feel the brush of sweaty bodies passing me

29.92.text: in the darkness, but I can't see much else.

34.16.text: I hear voices talking, but mostly the shaft

38.13.text: is this cacophony of men coughing,

42.12.text: and stone being broken with primitive tools.

46.03.text: Like the others, I wear a flickering, cheap flashlight

50.09.text: tied to my head with this elastic, tattered band,

54.88.text: and I can barely make out the slick tree limbs

58.22.text: holding up the walls of the three-foot square hole

61.25.text: dropping hundreds of feet into the earth.

65.88.text: When my hand slips, I suddenly remember a miner

68.96.text: I had met days before who had lost his grip

73.24.text: and fell countless feet down that shaft.

77.86.text: As I stand talking to you today,

80.39.text: these men are still deep in that hole,

83.89.text: risking their lives without payment or compensation,

90.55.text: I got to climb out of that hole, and I got to go home,

95.74.text: but they likely never will, because they're trapped in slavery.

101.92.text: For the last 28 years, I've been documenting

104.83.text: indigenous cultures in more than 70 countries

107.39.text: on six continents, and in 2009 I had the great honor

111.18.text: of being the sole exhibitor at the Vancouver Peace Summit.

115.59.text: Amongst all the astonishing people I met there,

119.17.text: I met a supporter of Free the Slaves, an NGO

122.34.text: dedicated to eradicating modern day slavery.

127.66.text: We started talking about slavery, and really,

133.42.text: for I had certainly known it existed in the world,

136.62.text: but not to such a degree.

139.64.text: After we finished talking, I felt so horrible

143.38.text: and honestly ashamed at my own lack of knowledge

146.75.text: of this atrocity in my own lifetime, and I thought,

150.26.text: if I don't know, how many other people don't know?

155.13.text: It started burning a hole in my stomach, so within weeks,

158.95.text: I flew down to Los Angeles to meet with the director

161.92.text: of Free the Slaves and offer them my help.

165.19.text: Thus began my journey into modern day slavery.

169.76.text: Oddly, I had been to many of these places before.

172.91.text: Some I even considered like my second home.

176.39.text: But this time, I would see the skeletons hidden in the closet.

183.82.text: A conservative estimate tells us there are more than

186.13.text: 27 million people enslaved in the world today.

190.28.text: That's double the amount of people taken from Africa

193.76.text: during the entire trans-Atlantic slave trade.

197.89.text: A hundred and fifty years ago, an agricultural slave

201.03.text: cost about three times the annual salary

207.27.text: That equates to about $50,000 in today's money.

211.26.text: Yet today, entire families can be enslaved for generations

215.66.text: over a debt as small as $18.

223.56.text: of more than $13 billion worldwide each year.

229.30.text: Many have been tricked by false promises

232.15.text: of a good education, a better job, only to find

236.70.text: that they're forced to work without pay

240.21.text: under the threat of violence, and they cannot walk away.

249.16.text: so the goods that enslaved people produce have value,

253.19.text: but the people producing them are disposable.

258.19.text: Slavery exists everywhere, nearly, in the world,

262.58.text: and yet it is illegal everywhere in the world.

269.54.text: In India and Nepal, I was introduced to the brick kilns.

274.33.text: This strange and awesome sight was like

277.12.text: walking into ancient Egypt or Dante's Inferno.

285.17.text: men, women, children, entire families in fact,

289.26.text: were cloaked in a heavy blanket of dust,

292.41.text: while mechanically stacking bricks on their head,

295.03.text: up to 18 at a time, and carrying them

298.15.text: from the scorching kilns to trucks hundreds of yards away.

306.63.text: they work silently, doing this task over and over

315.57.text: There were no breaks for food, no water breaks,

319.29.text: and the severe dehydration made urinating

324.71.text: So pervasive was the heat and the dust

327.14.text: that my camera became too hot to even touch

333.35.text: Every 20 minutes, I'd have to run back to our cruiser

336.12.text: to clean out my gear and run it under an air conditioner

339.47.text: to revive it, and as I sat there,

342.52.text: I thought, my camera is getting far better treatment

349.46.text: Back in the kilns, I wanted to cry,

352.33.text: but the abolitionist next to me quickly grabbed me

355.51.text: and he said, "Lisa, don't do that. Just don't do that here."

359.81.text: And he very clearly explained to me that emotional displays

363.70.text: are very dangerous in a place like this,

366.24.text: not just for me, but for them.

370.09.text: I couldn't offer them any direct help.

373.74.text: I couldn't give them money, nothing.

376.54.text: I wasn't a citizen of that country.

378.33.text: I could get them in a worse situation

384.20.text: I'd have to rely on Free the Slaves to work

386.46.text: within the system for their liberation,

389.30.text: and I trusted that they would.

392.77.text: As for me, I'd have to wait until I got home

405.79.text: to trucks waiting at roads below.

408.69.text: The big sheets of slate were heavier

413.87.text: and the kids hoisted them from their heads

415.90.text: using these handmade harnesses of sticks and rope

422.19.text: It's difficult to witness something so overwhelming.

425.87.text: How can we affect something so insidious,

431.73.text: Some don't even know they're enslaved,

434.44.text: people working 16, 17 hours a day without any pay,

439.44.text: because this has been the case all their lives.

442.66.text: They have nothing to compare it to.

446.94.text: When these villagers claimed their freedom,

450.31.text: the slaveholders burned down all of their houses.

455.73.text: I mean, these people had nothing,

457.69.text: and they were so petrified, they wanted to give up,

461.34.text: but the woman in the center rallied for them to persevere,

466.88.text: helped them get a quarry lease of their own,

469.54.text: so that now they do the same back-breaking work,

472.65.text: but they do it for themselves, and they get paid for it,

477.16.text: and they do it in freedom.

482.65.text: when we hear the word slavery,

484.55.text: and because of this worldwide awareness,

498.85.text: They ushered me down a narrow set of stairs

501.21.text: that led to this dirty, dimly fluorescent lit basement.

506.82.text: This wasn't a brothel, per se.

508.65.text: It was more like a restaurant.

510.96.text: Cabin restaurants, as they're known in the trade,

515.84.text: Each has small, private rooms, where the slaves,

518.88.text: women, along with young girls and boys,

521.51.text: some as young as seven years old,

524.29.text: are forced to entertain the clients,

526.28.text: encouraging them to buy more food and alcohol.

530.06.text: Each cubicle is dark and dingy,

533.09.text: identified with a painted number on the wall,

537.03.text: and partitioned by plywood and a curtain.

541.14.text: The workers here often endure tragic sexual abuse

544.69.text: at the hands of their customers.

547.27.text: Standing in the near darkness, I remember feeling

550.34.text: this quick, hot fear, and in that instant,

554.42.text: I could only imagine what it must be like

556.77.text: to be trapped in that hell.

559.43.text: I had only one way out: the stairs from where I'd come in.

565.89.text: There were no windows large enough to climb through.

568.43.text: These people have no escape at all,

572.69.text: and as we take in such a difficult subject,

575.75.text: it's important to note that slavery, including sex trafficking,

580.36.text: occurs in our own backyard as well.

583.29.text: Tens of hundreds of people are enslaved in agriculture,

590.59.text: and the list can go on.

593.22.text: Recently, the New York Times reported that

601.67.text: are sold into sex slavery every year.

605.63.text: It's all around us. We just don't see it.

612.17.text: The textile industry is another one we often think of

615.55.text: when we hear about slave labor.

618.44.text: I visited villages in India where entire families were enslaved

627.70.text: The dyed black hands are the father, while the blue

631.59.text: and red hands are his sons.

634.37.text: They mix dye in these big barrels,

637.10.text: and they submerge the silk into the liquid up to their elbows,

646.03.text: My interpreter told me their stories.

652.93.text: "We hope still, though, that we could leave this house

657.69.text: where we actually get paid for our dyeing."

675.54.text: When we first arrived, I went to have a quick look.

678.51.text: I saw what seemed to be a family fishing on a boat,

681.88.text: two older brothers, some younger kids, makes sense right?

690.09.text: Children are taken from their families

695.43.text: and they're forced to work endless hours on these boats

698.34.text: on the lake, even though they do not know how to swim.

702.89.text: This young child is eight years old.

705.22.text: He was trembling when our boat approached,

707.88.text: frightened it would run over his tiny canoe.

710.53.text: He was petrified he would be knocked in the water.

713.87.text: The skeletal tree limbs submerged in Lake Volta

717.16.text: often catch the fishing nets, and weary,

721.12.text: frightened children are thrown into the water

729.85.text: For as long as he can recall, he's been forced to work

735.37.text: Terrified of his master, he will not run away,

738.83.text: and since he's been treated with cruelty all his life,

742.32.text: he passes that down to the younger slaves

747.75.text: I met these boys at five in the morning,

749.86.text: when they were hauling in the last of their nets,

752.32.text: but they had been working since 1 a.m.

758.76.text: And it's important to note that these nets weigh

762.02.text: more than a thousand pounds when they're full of fish.

766.44.text: I want to introduce you to Kofi.

770.94.text: Kofi was rescued from a fishing village.

774.19.text: I met him at a shelter where Free the Slaves

780.71.text: Here he's seen taking a bath at the well,

782.79.text: pouring big buckets of water over his head,

787.61.text: as you and I are sitting here talking today,

789.61.text: Kofi has been reunited with his family,

792.85.text: and what's even better, his family has been given tools

796.00.text: to make a living and to keep their children safe.

801.72.text: Kofi is the embodiment of possibility.

806.18.text: Who will he become because someone took a stand

810.75.text: and made a difference in his life?

814.34.text: Driving down a road in Ghana

816.57.text: with partners of Free the Slaves,

818.66.text: a fellow abolitionist on a moped suddenly sped up

821.70.text: to our cruiser and tapped on the window.

824.65.text: He told us to follow him down a dirt road into the jungle.

829.43.text: At the end of the road, he urged us out of the car,

832.21.text: and told the driver to quickly leave.

834.89.text: Then he pointed toward this barely visible footpath,

838.24.text: and said, "This is the path, this is the path. Go."

842.14.text: As we started down the path, we pushed aside the vines

845.80.text: blocking the way, and after about an hour of walking in,

849.60.text: found that the trail had become flooded by recent rains,

855.13.text: so I hoisted the photo gear above my head

856.95.text: as we descended into these waters up to my chest.

861.53.text: After another two hours of hiking, the winding trail

865.32.text: abruptly ended at a clearing, and before us

871.63.text: that could fit into the size of a football field,

875.45.text: and all of them were full of enslaved people laboring.

881.04.text: Many women had children strapped to their backs

884.19.text: while they were panning for gold,

886.23.text: wading in water poisoned by mercury.

890.53.text: Mercury is used in the extraction process.

895.41.text: These miners are enslaved in a mine shaft

901.64.text: When they came out of the shaft, they were soaking wet

906.74.text: I remember looking into their tired, bloodshot eyes,

910.74.text: for many of them had been underground for 72 hours.

916.48.text: The shafts are up to 300 feet deep, and they carry out

920.46.text: heavy bags of stone that later will be transported

924.03.text: to another area, where the stone will be pounded

926.63.text: so that they can extract the gold.

930.57.text: At first glance, the pounding site seems full

934.68.text: of powerful men, but when we look closer,

939.57.text: we see some less fortunate working on the fringes,

946.58.text: All of them are victim to injury, illness and violence.

953.72.text: In fact, it's very likely that this muscular person

957.70.text: will end up like this one here, racked with tuberculosis

962.24.text: and mercury poisoning in just a few years.

967.21.text: This is Manuru. When his father died,

971.49.text: his uncle trafficked him to work with him in the mines.

974.57.text: When his uncle died, Manuru inherited his uncle's debt,

979.16.text: which further forced him into being enslaved in the mines.

984.11.text: When I met him, he had been working in the mines

986.94.text: for 14 years, and the leg injury that you see here

991.73.text: is actually from a mining accident,

993.74.text: one so severe doctors say his leg should be amputated.

998.88.text: On top of that, Manuru has tuberculosis,

1002.83.text: yet he's still forced to work day in and day out

1008.12.text: Even still, he has a dream that he will become free

1013.28.text: and become educated with the help of local activists

1018.82.text: and it's this sort of determination,

1021.17.text: in the face of unimaginable odds,

1025.05.text: that fills me with complete awe.

1032.41.text: I want to shine a light on slavery.

1035.71.text: When I was working in the field,

1037.96.text: I brought lots of candles with me,

1040.65.text: and with the help of my interpreter,

1043.37.text: I imparted to the people I was photographing

1045.68.text: that I wanted to illuminate their stories

1050.86.text: so when it was safe for them, and safe for me,

1057.71.text: They knew their image would be seen

1059.94.text: by you out in the world.

1061.77.text: I wanted them to know that we will be bearing witness

1065.51.text: to them, and that we will do whatever we can

1069.44.text: to help make a difference in their lives.

1074.13.text: I truly believe, if we can see one another

1077.61.text: as fellow human beings, then it becomes very difficult

1087.30.text: These images are not of issues. They are of people,

1090.98.text: real people, like you and me, all deserving

1094.25.text: of the same rights, dignity and respect

1099.96.text: There is not a day that goes by that I don't think

1103.19.text: of these many beautiful, mistreated people

1108.47.text: I've had the tremendous honor of meeting.

1113.04.text: I hope that these images awaken a force

1116.57.text: in those who view them, people like you,

1119.62.text: and I hope that force will ignite a fire,

1123.89.text: and that fire will shine a light on slavery,

1128.82.text: for without that light, the beast of bondage

1132.83.text: can continue to live in the shadows.
